abstracts.cdata!:
The Structural Adjustment Credit (SAC)
            Project's outcome is rated as satisfactory,
            sustainability as likely, institutional development impact
            as modest, Bank performance as satisfactory, as Borrower
            performance as satisfactory. Key lessons learned from the
            implementation include: It is important to adequately take
            into account the political economy of the evolving
            situation. Delays in implementing certain of the agreed
            measures did lead to some reduction in effectiveness of the
            program supported under the SAC. Improved public expenditure
            management requires fundamental change in the
            Government's range of commitments. Post-privatization
            market development and support are needed to help contribute
            more quickly to an upswing in agricultural production and
            the development of rural wealth. For energy, as in the past
            the priority must be to bring in more competent private
            operators who have the technical know-how and financial
            resources to restore sector efficiency. Delays in
            privatization of attractive state enterprises, even in the
            fact of strong political opposition, should be avoided if at
            all possible.

            FOR MOLDOVA,TF037721-ECA REGION - TELECOMMUNICATIONS,TF024834-DUTCH GRANT IN SUPPORT OF THE

repnme.cdata!:
Moldova - Supplemental Credit to the Second
            Structural Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The November ice storm caused great
            damage to the power distribution network, as well as to
            telecommunications, forest, and agriculture. As a result,
            the power grid was down and related power infrastructure
            severely damaged, water supply, sewage systems, and
            telecommunications were not working, and as a result, many
            schools, hospitals, and businesses were unable to operate.
            An emergency response means up-front costs to the Government
            for Moldova for which they are re-channeling current
            revenues, a lowering of revenues available for expenditures
            in the 2001 budget. Supplemental resources will be disbursed
            throgh a Special Fund for National Calamities. And will
            partly finance import components (cables, tpwers, diesel
            fuel, etc.), some labor costs, and other domestic
            components. Any funds not directly and immediately used for
            emergency relief will constitute general external financing,
            and thus will be available to fund priority needs that
            earlier were delayed in order to re-channel funds to address
            ice storm damages. This supplement is crucial for
            maintaining momentum for the reform program described in the
            Interim Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (I-PRSP) and the
            Country Assistance Strategy, and supported by the Structural
            Adjustment Credit.

            FOR MOLDOVA,TF037721-ECA REGION - TELECOMMUNICATIONS,TF024834-DUTCH GRANT IN SUPPORT OF THE

repnme.cdata!:
Moldova - Second Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Structural Adjustment Credit
            Project (SAC III) supports the Government reform program,
            which is necessary to create conditions for a resumption of
            growth and an improvement of the living standards in
            Moldova. To achieve this goal, the SAC III is designed to
            carry forward the reform program started under the Second
            Structural Adjustment Loan Project (SAL II)(report number
            P7139). SAL II focused on four areas: pension reform; land
            privatization and farm restructuring; unbundling the energy
            enterprises and starting the process of privatization; and
            enterprise privatization, particularly on a small scale. SAC
            III will focus on continuing the privatization process in
            agriculture, energy, and the enterprise sector. In
            agriculture, the focus will be on maintaining momentum for
            land reform, supporting new private farmers, and laying the
            foundations for a restructuring of agro-processing. In
            energy, the Credit will support completion of the
            privatization process for electricity distribution companies
            as well as substantive progress towards privatizing the
            electricity generation companies and the gas company. It
            will also initiate a process that should lead to privatizing
            the district heating companies. Finally, the Credit will
            support implementation of a new enterprise privatization
            program covering the years 1999-2000 which will emphasize
            the importance of attracting strategic investors to Moldova.
            The Credit will be released in two tranches.

Moldova - Second Structural Adjustment
